title: 3 Quick Cake Icing Recipes Anyone Can Make

steps.title: Dump 1 c (200 g) of powdered sugar into a large bowl.
steps.content: Dump 1 c (200 g) of powdered sugar into a large bowl. Also known as confectioner’s sugar, powdered sugar is the base of this quick cake icing. [1] X Expert Source JoAnna Minneci Professional Chef Expert Interview. 23 December 2021. This recipe makes about 1 cup (200 g) of frosting but can be easily adjusted by adding more or less powdered sugar. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pour 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of milk or lemon juice over the sugar.
steps.content: Pour 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of milk or lemon juice over the sugar. The great thing about this recipe is it’s extremely universal, and depending on the flavor you want to add, you can use milk, lemon juice, or other fruit juices. [3] X Expert Source JoAnna Minneci Professional Chef Expert Interview. 23 December 2021. Adding milk makes a sweet and rich icing, while using lemon juice creates a light and citrusy glaze. Remember, it’s always better to add too little liquid than too much, so add your milk or juice in small increments. Keep in mind that the color of your liquid will change the color of your icing. For instance, grape juice would make a purple or pink glaze.

steps.title: Stir the mixture with a spoon or whisk.
steps.content: Stir the mixture with a spoon or whisk. Use gentle stirring motions to bring the sugar and liquid together, making sure not to knock any out of the bowl. Continue stirring until a paste forms. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add more liquid until all the dry sugar is incorporated.
steps.content: Add more liquid until all the dry sugar is incorporated. Keep pouring milk or juice into the mixture in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) increments until the icing reaches your desired consistency. For a pourable glaze, aim for a thin and watery mixture. For thicker icing, try for a blended puree consistency. [5] X Research source If your mixture gets too runny, add more powdered sugar.

steps.title: Mix in a few drops of vanilla or almond extract.
steps.content: Mix in a few drops of vanilla or almond extract. Finish off your icing with a flavor extract of your choice. Stir in the flavor until everything is well combined, and you’re ready to spoon or pour your sugar icing over your cake. [6] X Research source Use food coloring to change the color of your icing for a more festive look. Add cocoa in 1 tsp (2.5 g) increments to make chocolate icing. [7] X Expert Source JoAnna Minneci Professional Chef Expert Interview. 23 December 2021. Store cakes with powdered sugar glaze in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Soften 1 cup (200 g) of butter.
steps.content: Soften 1 cup (200 g) of butter. The quickest way to soften butter is to place it in a microwave-safe dish and microwave it for 10 to 30 seconds. If you don’t have a microwave, cut the butter into small pieces and leave it on the counter for 4 hours before using it. [9] X Research source If you don’t have butter, use margarine; however, the icing may have an oilier flavor and thinner consistency. Softened butter is the perfect temperature when you can push your finger in it with little pressure. [10] X Expert Source Maha Mohamed Custom Dessert Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2022.

steps.title: Beat the softened butter and powdered sugar together.
steps.content: Beat the softened butter and powdered sugar together. Put the softened butter in a large bowl and start beating with an electric mixer. Gradually add 3 cups (600 g) of powdered sugar while mixing. Start at a low speed, then increase to a medium speed once the sugar is incorporated with the butter. [11] X Expert Source Maha Mohamed Custom Dessert Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2022. If you don’t have an electric mixer, no worries! Beat the ingredients by hand using a spoon, fork, or whisk. The longer you beat your frosting, the fluffier and lighter it’ll be.

steps.title: Add 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of whipping cream and 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract.
steps.content: Add 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of whipping cream and 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract. Beat the mixture until the frosting is fluffy and one uniform color. If it spreads thickly and evenly off a knife, it’s good to go. [12] X Research source Otherwise, troubleshoot as follows: If the icing is too soft, beat in more powdered sugar in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) intervals until it’s thick enough to spread or place in the fridge for a few minutes. [13] X Expert Source Maha Mohamed Custom Dessert Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2022. If the icing is too thick or cracks when spread, add water or cream in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) intervals until it’s soft and spreadable. Try using heavy cream and almond extract instead of whipping cream and vanilla extract for a richer taste.

steps.title: Toss in additional flavors or colors if you’d like.
steps.content: Toss in additional flavors or colors if you’d like. This step is optional but can add a special flair to traditional cake frosting. Use a flavor that compliments your cake, or add food coloring that matches the occasion’s decor. Try adding 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of lemon juice or zest if you baked an angel food cake. Make a rich chocolate buttercream for a vanilla cake by adding 4 oz (118 g) of melted baking chocolate while mixing. Toss in 2 tsp (9.9 mL) of instant coffee to give a chocolate cake some mocha flavor. Use a few drops of red food coloring to make a pink icing fit for a princess party.

steps.title: Store buttercream frosting in an airtight container.
steps.content: Store buttercream frosting in an airtight container. Believe it or not, buttercream doesn’t have to go into the fridge immediately. Once made, this cake frosting can last at room temperature in an airtight container for 2 days. Place any remaining frosting or cake in the fridge after 2 days to be enjoyed for at least another week. [14] X Research source Consider storing your frosting in the freezer if you made too much. Fill a sealable bag or freezer-safe container with frosting, and keep it in the freezer for up to 3 months.

steps.title: Soften ½ c (100 g) of butter and 1 c (200 g) of cream cheese.
steps.content: Soften ½ c (100 g) of butter and 1 c (200 g) of cream cheese. Place each item in the microwave for 10 to 30 seconds, or cut them into chunks and leave them on the counter for a few hours. The butter and cheese are ready when they’re soft to the touch, not melted. [15] X Research source If you prefer the taste of normal buttercream frosting, use double the amount of butter and half the amount of cream cheese, as this will give you a creamy frosting without all the cheese flavor. Opt for full-fat cream cheese, as low-fat cream cheese could make the frosting runny.

steps.title: Beat the softened butter and cream cheese together in a bowl.
steps.content: Beat the softened butter and cream cheese together in a bowl. Use an electric mixer (if you have one) and cream the ingredients until they’re light and fluffy. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a fork or knife to ensure there are no clumps. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in 2 c (400 g) of powdered sugar in ½ c (100 g) increments.
steps.content: Stir in 2 c (400 g) of powdered sugar in ½ c (100 g) increments. After thoroughly mixing the butter and cream cheese, gradually add the powdered sugar to the bowl. Pour in ½ cup (100 g) of powdered sugar, mix until combined, and then pour in another ½ cup (100 g). Continue adding and mixing until 2 cups (400 g) of powdered sugar is incorporated. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Beat the frosting until it’s light and fluffy.
steps.content: Beat the frosting until it’s light and fluffy. Continue to mix the icing until it reaches your desired consistency. If you’re not sure whether it's fluffy enough, stop. Overmixing could cause the dairy to melt and make a runny frosting. If your frosting is too runny, add more cream cheese and powdered sugar to thicken the frosting .

steps.title: Flavor your frosting with 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract.
steps.content: Flavor your frosting with 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract. Stir in 1 tsp (4.9 mL) of vanilla extract and/or food coloring. Mix the frosting until everything is well incorporated and no streaks of flavoring or coloring are visible. Now all that’s left to do is spread your cream cheese frosting onto your cake and enjoy! [18] X Research source Top a red velvet cake with this frosting for a traditional pairing, or spread it onto a chocolate chip cookie for a decadent treat. Store leftover icing and a cream cheese frosted cake in the fridge within 2 hours of making to avoid spoilage. [19] X Research source
